bioghist.p: The Babies' Hospital of Philadelphia was opened at the Country Branch of Children's Hospital in Wynnefield, Pennsylvania on July 11, 1911, and was incorporated in November 1911 with Charles A. Fife serving as its first president. The following year, the hospital secured the use of the Presbyterian Hospital's convalescent home in Devon for recovered babies who required additional care. In 1913, the Babies' Hospital opened a clinic, dispensary, and milk station on 729 Lombard Street in the city of Philadelphia. The clinic provided numerous services, including instruction courses for expectant mothers. The following year, another dispensary was opened at 609 Addison Street. By 1918, this dispensary had moved to larger quarters on Ninth and Pine Streets. In 1915, a permanent home for the country hospital was established in Llanerch, Pennsylvania. 1920 marked the opening of the Ethel Burnham Worcester Memorial Cottage, a "seashore branch" of the hospital located in Beach Haven, New Jersey. The main concern of the Babies' Hospital was its social services, which emphasized preventive medicine, good nutrition and hygiene, and the proper care of babies in the home. To house its growing facilities, the hospital built a six story Health Center Building at 7th and Delancey Streets, which was dedicated in May 1921. In 1948, the funds and resources of Babies' Hospital of Philadelphia and the Philadelphia Child Health Society were merged into the Fife Hamill Memorial Health Center for Southeast Philadelphia. The new organization was housed in the Health Center Building formerly occupied by the Babies' Hospital. When the Fife Hamill Memorial Health Center closed in 1960, the Corporation of Babies' Hospital was merged with St. Christopher's Hospital for Children.

scopecontent.p: This collection contains miscellaneous records of the Babies' Hospital of Philadelphia. Printed materials include annual reports (1911-1930); Babies' Hospital and Babies' News (1915-1921); benefit matinee programs (1915-1921); and miscellaneous printed material. Corporate records include a ledger for the Charles A. Fife Memorial Fund kept by the Women's Committee (1929-1937); and minutes of the Medical Administration Committee (1940-1948). There are also papers of H. Lea Hudson, 1932-1960; by-laws, histories, and list of officers of Babies' Hospital of Philadelphia; and correspondence and historical material related to the Fife-Hamill Memorial Health Center for Southeast Philadelphia. There are also photographs and film of the Babies' Hospital dated 1941-1942.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
